messages.subject: Introduction, and response to "bad superior attitude"
messages.msgSnippet: Wow, I guess I d better slip my intro in quick cause I ve been lurking for the last few days, and feel like I want to respond to what Robyn is experiencing
messages.messageBody:
Wow, I guess I'd better slip my intro in quick cause I've been lurking
for the last few days, and feel like I want to respond to what Robyn is
experiencing with Jayn and her "friend" . . .

My name is Trina, DH Rob and DS Elijah, 1YO; we have a lot of interest
in unschooling and gentle living, and a lot to learn, which is why I'm
really glad to be on this list! Right now DS's field of study is dirt,
mud, dogs, rocks, flowers and weeds. I love how mellow and centered he
gets just being outside, and how occupied he keeps himself.

I am relatively new to the world of online discussions and am astonished
and really excited at the level of community that seems to come together
this way. We're living in a small land-based community in northern New
Mexico, and love our community partners, who welcome and honor our
"unconventional" parenting style. My main beef is that we're the only
family, and that I (at 33) am the youngest except for DS! LOL we're
open to this shifting, in a good and organic way.

So what came up for me while reading your sharing Robyn . . . When I was
finishing fourth grade, our parents (of 9 children) announced that they
were taking us out of school. I loved being trusted with my own
learning process, and so enjoyed being able to follow my own passions as
they grew and shifted and branched out. YUMMM!

Only difficult thing was, there were few others in our area who were
home-schooling as well. There was one girl my age who I hung out with
constantly. I didn't really like her, but for some reason had a hard
time pulling myself out of the "tractor beam" of being with her. She
effectively dominated the space between us and always decided what we
would do and how we would do it. I really felt like a nothing. I know
my mom occasionally tried to discourage our "friendship" but I
stubbornly insisted on continuing this numbing experience. My mom
recently remarked on how mean she was to me -- why did I continue to
hang out with her?

I still can't answer that question. The interesting thing to me was,
though, what changed for me, that helped me move on:

A few years into this experience, my Mom started seeking counseling,
doing her own inner work, trying with huge effort to contradict the
heavy inner and outer messages that said that she didn't matter. She
started exploring her creative side, writing, painting, and asking the
question "what do *I* want?".

This work that Mom did was a small earthquake that shook up just about
everything in our lives. It was around this time that I made some
decisions in my life, which essentially spelled the end of me hanging
out with this girl.

I don't know what it is like for you, Robyn, and my story may be way way
off topic for what you experience, but it reminded me again how potent
my mama's example of self-care was, and is, for me. Thanks for
reminding me.

Blessings . . .
Trina
